item.title: Anne Heyman, Rwanda Rescuer, Is Dead at 52
item.description: Ms. Heyman found in Israel’s system of youth villages a model for assisting the young survivors of the Rwandan genocide.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: The Lede: Turkey Deports Journalist for Criticizing Government on Twitter
item.description: Turkey deported an Azerbaijani journalist on Friday for “posting tweets against high-level state officials,” according to an Interior Ministry order obtained by his newspaper, the English-language daily Today’s Zaman.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Taking On Thailand’s Crisis With a Bit of Western Bite
item.description: “Shallow News in Depth,” founded by two Thai-Americans, uses acid-laced sarcasm in a style called “Jon Stewart on crack.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winyu Wongsurawat, left, working on his low-budget political satire show with his sister, Janya Wongsurawat, and Nattapong Tiendee, in their studio in Bangkok on Thursday.

item.title: The Lede: Protesters Sack Government Offices Across Bosnia
item.description: As protesters fed up with economic and political stagnation sacked government buildings in cities across Bosnia on Friday, journalists and bloggers shared images and firsthand accounts of the unrest on social networks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Far-Right Party Strains to Hang On in Britain
item.description: The British National Party, which won two seats in the European Parliament in 2009, is riven by infighting and is now on the edge of political oblivion.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Iran Says It Will Cooperate With U.N. Nuclear Inquiry
item.description: Iran has told diplomats that it plans to cooperate this weekend with United Nations experts investigating alleged activities that it has steadfastly denied: work on nuclear weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: No Ukraine Inquiry Into Bugged Phone Call
item.description: Ukraine’s state security service is not looking into the taping of a phone call that embarrassed American diplomats.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 2 Die as Boulder Hits French Train
item.description: A boulder from a mountain smashed into a train in the French Alps, killing two passengers and injuring several others.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Virus Advances Through East Caribbean
item.description: The spread of Chikungunya fever, a painful mosquito-borne virus, is a once-distant illness that public health experts fear will become entrenched throughout the region.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: James Gathany/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Aedes aegypti mosquito carries Chikungunya fever.

item.title: White House Memo: French Breakup Makes a Dinner Harder to Do
item.description: President François Hollande of France will apparently be coming stag to a White House state dinner, which complicates more than just seating.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France is apparently coming stag to a White House state dinner, which complicates things.

item.title: China Exhibit, Part of an Anti-Japan Campaign, Reflects an Escalating Feud
item.description: An exhibit about a Korean nationalist who assassinated a Japanese politician in 1909 is indicative of the anti-Japanese public relations campaign that China is running.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display at the Harbin railway station in China celebrating a Japanese leader’s assassin is one measure in a public relations effort.

item.title: Wielding Whip and a Hard New Law, Nigeria Tries to ‘Sanitize’ Itself of Gays
item.description: Since Nigeria’s president signed a law criminalizing homosexuality, arrests of gay people have multiplied and demands for a crackdown have flourished.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Benedicte Kurzen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A judge in Bauchi, in mostly Muslim northern Nigeria, re-enacted the lashing of a man convicted of homosexuality.

item.title: Afghan Forces’ Killings of Civilians Rose in 2013
item.description: A United Nations report shows a rise in civilian casualties, with a reduced share of those attributed to international forces.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition in Kabul of photographs of war casualties from the last three decades.

item.title: Program Benefiting Some Immigrants Extends Visa Wait for Others
item.description: A push to defer deportations for young undocumented immigrants has meant delays in granting green cards to relatives of citizens, usually a comparatively swift process.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Bachert in the temporary apartment he has been renting near his company’s headquarters in Hartford. His wife, children and dogs remain in Australia, waiting.

item.title: Intrigue, Conspiracy, Alien Abduction: Politics of Chess Go Off the Board
item.description: The intrigue revolves around corruption allegations by the two candidates for the federation’s presidency, Garry Kasparov, the former champion and Russian opposition figure, and Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the incumbent president.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
item.media:description: Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion, observed a match in January.

item.title: Economic View: Why Emerging Markets Should Look Within
item.description: Self-inflicted political wounds, more than global economic tides, appear to be shaking nations like Argentina, Turkey, Ukraine and Thailand.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER COWEN

item.title: Strategies: The Greater the Turmoil, the Stronger the Dollar. Again.
item.description: A familiar pattern is back in currency markets, even if U.S. policy is fueling some of the world’s financial problems.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Scores Detained in Russia Before Olympic Ceremony
item.description: Russian authorities detained at least 61 people on Friday for holding unauthorized protests, underscoring the government’s efforts to stifle dissent.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: McDonald’s Opens in Vietnam, Bringing Big Mac to Fans of Banh Mi
item.description: The fast-food giant is opening its first restaurant in the country, which some see as one of Asia’s last consumer markets with significant untapped potential.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE IVES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Supporters Call for Investigation Into Death of Chinese Activist’s Father
item.description: The authorities in Shandong Province told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurator’s office building in the city of Qufu.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Xue Mingkai, whose father, Xue Fushun, died under disputed circumstances.

item.title: Guatemalan Court Upholds Top Prosecutor's Ouster
item.description: Guatemala's Supreme Court on Friday upheld its ruling that the country's crusading attorney general must step down in May, seven months before her term was set to end, drawing complaints from human rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 2 Former Premiers Try to Use Tokyo Election to Rally Public Against Nuclear Power
item.description: Former Prime Ministers Morihiro Hosokawa and Junichiro Koizumi are trying to turn the election for Tokyo governor on Sunday into a referendum on the future of nuclear power in Japan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Yoichi Masuzoe is the governing party’s candidate for Tokyo governor.

item.title: U.S. Prisoner in North Korea Gets Consular Visit
item.description: A Swedish diplomat visited Kenneth Bae, who has been imprisoned in North Korea for more than a year, his family reported, as speculation grew over potential talks to free him.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Deception Foils Attempt to Hijack Turkish Jet to Sochi
item.description: Turkish officials said a passenger claiming a bomb was aboard wanted the aircraft diverted to Sochi, but it landed in Istanbul and he was arrested.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: So Many Bribes, a Greek Official Can’t Recall Them All
item.description: The testimony by a deputy in the Defense Ministry, if accurate, illustrates how arms makers from Germany, France, Sweden and Russia passed out payoffs to sell Greece weaponry that it could ill afford.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Greek Defense Ministry paid more than $4 billion for submarines that sit virtually abandoned in a shipyard outside Athens.
